SENT.plain: In this article, front-line immunosuppressive therapy (IST) for acquired plastic anemia (AA) is illustrated and discussed
Also second-line and salvage options are briefly illustrated
First-line IST should consist of horse anti-thymocyte globulin (ATG) and CsA that has been shown to result in response rates between 60 and 80%
CsA should be given for 12 months until transfusion independence is achieved and then tapered very slowly in the presence of a CR
Patients with a partial response are usually continued on CsA
Tight monitoring of the blood count during CsA tapering is necessary to identify early loss of response

G-CSF 5 μg/kg/day s.c. in the first 30 days has been shown to reduce infections and hospitalization and to identify early responders, as those who achieve neutrophils count of0.5 × 10(9)/L by day +30
This schedule is recommended in the first month of therapy
Afterward, G-CSF can be considered in neutropenic febrile episodes

Patients not achieving transfusion independence after a first course of IST may be considered for second-line IST, or for an allogeneic hematopoietic SCT depending on patient age, ongoing infection, neutrophil count and transfusion requirements
Third-line IST is rarely given, but some options are discussed
